comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: Perhaps Anthony Gustav de Rothschild -- he'd have been about 27 in 1914. A rich heir and horse breeder at this time, he went on to bigger things: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthony_Gustav_de_Rothschild It could also be his brother Evelyn, about the same age and a banker, who was killed in WWI. I can't find other photos of either to compare.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: He and his companions stand before a half-timbered building that could be Medieval, or Elizabethan.

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: I assumed M for Monsieur, but I dunno.  And the building has a very tall door, like a barn.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
If this is Anthony Gustav, it is an interesting coincidence that his son, Sir Evelyn Robert Adrian de Rothschild (born in 1931, and named for the uncle who died in WWI), happens to be a member of the board of the Globe Shakespeare Trust: admirers of the Bard, who recently reconstructed Shakespeare's half-timbered Globe Theatre, on its original site, in London.

Anthony Gustav in 1939 inherited his father's estate, Ascott House, a pseudo-Tudor fantasy built in the nineteenth century, in the half-timbered style:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/rowanbank/5662318422/]
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/peatc/3600634816/in/photostream/]
I wonder if Bain's photo shows the barn on the Ascott estate?
Or perhaps a streetscape in Shakespeare's Stratford-Upon-Avon? {When I was there in 1985, there was a McDonald's restaurant on the same avenue as Shakespeare's house. It's probably there still.}
